name: Matrix Third Room
summary: Back when the VRChat debacle took place, I‚Äôd rambled quite a lot about the idea of a standards-based truly-distributed VR system. I probably mentioned how back in the day I was designing something like that, and was intending to use XMPP as the actual transport mechanism; in my more recent reevaluation of the idea I was thinking that using WebRTC to stream the actual realtime data (voice, character animation, etc.) would be the way forward.

content.html:
Some eight years ago, I stumbled upon an irreparable ‚Äô50s radio and turned it into a Pi-powered audio player.


That is, I gave it a fresh coat of paint and a new grill cloth, and built in two small-ish speakers and an equally small ‚ÄúClass D‚Äù amp. The thing‚Äôs driven by a Raspberry Pi equipped with the cheapest of USB ‚Äúsound cards.‚Äù


The Pi runs MPD, and, alongside it, mpdscribble, a simple audio scrobbling service. Had it push song data to Last.fm‚Äîwhich I hadn‚Äôt used in years‚Äîfor quite a while. And while that was fun, I ultimately decided to pull the plug. (I mean, ‚ÄúWho even cares?‚Äù)


Fast-forward to today, or rather, a month or so ago, when I saw all of the year-end Spotify banners fly by, and thought, ‚ÄúHey, I could totally do this and retain ownership of my data.‚Äù


So, I looked at Libre.fm‚Äôs source code‚ÄîLibre.fm being an open-source but somewhat outdated Last.fm alternative‚Äîand drew inspiration from it for a WordPress plugin of my own. (Of course, I later on discovered that such a plugin already existed.)


Luckily, mpdscribble‚Äôs config file‚Äîfound at /etc/mpdscribble.conf‚Äîallows setting the Libre.fm endpoint. Pointed it to my site instead, and ‚Ä¶ it worked!


Next up was scrobbling from my Windows computer. I vaguely remember Last.fm‚Äôs Audioscrobbler plugins for, e.g., Winamp, but those would obviously have Last.fm‚Äôs endpoint hardcoded within (and have updated to the newer scrobbling protocol, while my endpoint only accepts the much older 1.2 version).


Anyhow, long story short: I mostly followed this Reddit post and used a hex editor to replace the default endpoint of a somewhat older foobar2000 plugin with my own! (The rest of the post isn‚Äôt super relevant.) Had to shorten my URL a bit to make it all fit, but: this, too, ended up working!


So ‚Ä¶ the result‚Äôs up at /listens. I‚Äôm still figuring out how to microformat these; don‚Äôt think too many parsers support listen-of.

Pointed it to my site instead, and ‚Ä¶ it worked!Next up was scrobbling from my Windows computer. I vaguely remember Last.fm‚Äôs Audioscrobbler plugins for, e.g., Winamp, but those would obviously have Last.fm‚Äôs endpoint hardcoded within (and have updated to the newer scrobbling protocol, while my endpoint only accepts the much older 1.2 version).Anyhow, long story short: I mostly followed this Reddit post and used a hex editor to replace the default endpoint of a somewhat older foobar2000 plugin with my own!           fit into what I'd consider a blog post but also would need a permalink.

content.html: I want to squeeze https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/blob/master/packages/adapter-node/src/handler.js into Rust somehow so I can get the SSR/CSR benefits of SvelteKit but from within Rust so I can use my own server. I wonder if I can do this somehow using WebAssembly.

content.html: Been debugging an issue in Sele for three hours, pulled in a mitm proxy tool only to finally see the issue in my tests once I bubbled up the error from another library I've written. The call's within the house!
